comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The date "pre March 1883" is way off - the Anderson Stuart Building was completed in 1891, so this photo must be c.1890. Designed by Edmund Blacket (University Architect) - I thought that might be him in the top hat, but he died in 1883 - adb.anu.edu.au/biography/blacket-edmund-thomas-3005. Fascinating to see how the building was built - sandstone carved on site and lifted on flimsy wooden gantry and scaffolding. That would have been hard work.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content:
timber gantry?
how do they cope without a crane for  all that sandstone?

ie: we want that 2 ton block here, but now 2 feet to the left?

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Yes - you're right c. 1890 would be more appropriate! From the University of Sydney website "1891 The first part of the Anderson Stuart Building was completed" sydney.edu.au/medicine/museum/mwmuseum/index.php/Key_dates .

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] There's lots still to find out about this photo. Some sources say James Barnet was the architect - imho he was completing Blacket's design. It could be a little earlier than 1890 because there is a photo dated 1890 from St Andrews College, showing the Medical School at right - sydney.edu.au/arms/archives/media/me_objects/9 . This is the EASTERN Elevation of the original double-H design - there were later additions to the north / right of photo - Bing - binged.it/TDjROp GoogleMapsSatelliteView - maps.google.com.au/maps?q=Sydney+NSW&hl=en&ll=-33... "Sir Topham Hatt" has me puzzled - he looks so like Blacket, and not like Barnet. He appears proudly in another view (the north elevation under construction) - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp....

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Here we go - Description of the building as being nearly completed and anticipating an official opening in January 1888 (the Centennial) - SMH 8/11/1887 p.9 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13670150 So earlier date for this photo 1887? And James Barnet WAS the architect - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13580843

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I wonder if it is Sir William Montagu Manning (1811-1895), aged about 75, at the time Chancellor of Sydney University (1878-95). And his grandchildren? [golly, I get way too involved with these photos ...]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Earlier still! October 1886 - " ... The masonry is of a highly finished character, and now reveals the massiveness of the structure as well as its imposing architectural features. ... " - SMH 28/10/1886 p.5 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13618857
